Before ETV stations took to the air, a nucleus of
the ETV movement operated over commercial tel¬
evision facilities. While it was helping build ETV,
the Ford Foundation began “Omnibus,” an ex¬
periment to determine whether high-caliber adult,
cultural television could compete for a large and
loyal audience on a commercial-television net¬
work. ‘ ‘ Omnibus’ ’ ’ ninety-minute weekly telecasts
began in November, 1952. It pioneered in history,
music, biography, and drama. It won forty-eight
major awards and an average audience of twenty
million viewers for each program. The Founda¬
tion gave “Omnibus” a net subsidy of $3.1 mil¬
lion. By 1957, the Foundation concluded that the
experiment had demonstrated the wide accept¬
ability of “Omnibus.” The subsidy ended, and
“Omnibus” has continued on commercial net¬
works under other auspices.
To sustain community support, ETV stations had
to have enough good program material to remain
on the air more than two or three hours a day,
five days a week. Embryonic stations could not
afford extensive live programming. ETV dipped
into millions of feet of “educational film” and
found it dated or generally unsuitable for aes¬
thetic, legal, and technical reasons. To meet the
after-school programming needs of ETV stations,
the Educational Television and Radio Center was
established in 1953 and has since been supported
by the Ford Foundation. It is viewed through
